720548f-a.text:
Hudson Street, east side, north from Barrow Street, showing the old two-story structures with slanting roof and gables which were typical of this district in the latter part of the Nineteenth Century and first few yesrs of the Twentieth. No. 464 on the corner of Barrow Street, and Nos. 466 to 480, which are frame houses with brick facing, are about to be replaced by a new brick apartment house. Beyond Public School No. 3, at the north corner of Grove Street, notice the new building at 494-496, which has replaced the old houses shown at that site in 1912 when the Public School was being built.
April, 1925.
Brown Brothers.
720548f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

720551f-a.text:
465-477, 481, 487-489 Hudson Street, west side, from Barrow Street towards Christopher Street. In the center of the block stands St. Luke's Chapel, one of the older church buildings in New York, erected in 1821. It is now a part of Trinity Parish. No. 487, the first
building north of the church, is the parish house.
October 1, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
720551f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

720549f-a.text:
(1)
Hudson Street, east side, from Barrow (right) to Grove (left) Streets, as seen from the U.S. Appraisers Stores. Shown is a general view eastward, over the Greenwich Village Section.
July 25, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same; and showing also the rears of buildings on the west side of Hudson Street. Note St. Luke's P.E. Chapel, at the head of Grove
Street.
July 25, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
720549f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

720552f-a.text:
475-477, 481, 487-499 Hudson Street, west side, rear view, from north of Barrow to Christopher Streets.
June 25, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
720552f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

724941f-a.text:
Hdson Street (across view from right to left) north from Barrow Street, showirg a general view of St. Lukes P.E. Chapel and vicinity as photomraphed in a generallv eastward direction fror atop the U.S. Appraisers Stores (Custom House). The Church faces Grove Street hich Pas P.S. No. 3 on the northerlv side of same. Christophed Street is the next street north. Tis area in tke midorormnd is better known as Greenwich Village ard consists
rainly of srall huildings.
July 25, 1930.
Views 1 and 2
P.L. Sperr
724941f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

720550f-a.text:
Hudson Street, west side, between Barrow and Christopher Streets, showing St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Chapel. In the left background is the U. S. Appraisers Stores building.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the p blished volume "Portrait of N. Y." by F lix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
720550f-a.folder: Hudson Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

720553f-b.text:
(1)
St. Luke's Chapel (Protestant Episcopal, Trinity Parish), 481 Hudson Street, opposite the western end of Grove Street, between Barrow and Christopher Streets. This is one of the older church
edifices in the city, having been built in 1821.
1914.
Gift of Samuel Landsman:
(2)
The church, fifteen years later, seen from the southeast.
June, 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(3)
The same as (2), seen from the northeast. The building in the background is the Federal Building and Post Office on Washington Street.
June, 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
720553f-b.folder: Hudson Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY
